Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WWB-JNB1-JBJ7-N53G-00000-00Social media escapes as old media faces Christchurch censure2019-03-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisSocial media escapes as old media faces Christchurch censureMax Mason and Paul Smith

Australian broadcasters will be subject to a formal investigation by regulators for broadcasting the Christchurch terrorist attack, but Facebook isn't included.

Australian television broadcasters are facing a formal investigation into their coverage of the Christchurch terrorist attack last Friday, while the online platforms that facilitated the rapid spread of the massacre, such as Facebook, Google and Twitter, are being left to self-censorship.

On Monday, the Australian Communications and Media Authority launched an investigation to discover whether content rules were breached by free-to-air and subscription television networks coverage of the attack by a white supremacist on a mosque in Christchurch last week.

Facebook, YouTube (which is owned by Google), and Twitter have come under sustained international pressure following Friday's terrorist attack. The gunman used Facebook to livestream a 17-minute video of the attack and used Twitter to disseminate his manifesto.

The video was downloaded, edited and shared repeatedly across the three social media platforms as well as in various forms on anonymous online forums 4chan, 8chan and Reddit.

Despite the content being widely viewed on Facebook, Google and Twitter are safe from any punishment under ACMA's remit.

When asked about the consequences for Facebook, Twitter or Google a spokeswoman for Communications Minister Mitch Fifield directed The Australian Financial Review to the office of the eSafety Commissioner.

However, the eSafety Commissioner has limited power and said it could only issue takedown orders when content is hosted or streamed in Australia -the content is largely being taken down by the platforms.

It said it had reached out to the social media companies to see how they are handling the situation.

"eSafety can take removal action on versions of the video being shared on websites hosted in Australia. Footage of this attack can be reported to eSafety's Cyberreport team for investigation. Since Friday's incident, 59 reports have been received and our investigators are currently assessing the content."

ACMA said its investigation will focus on any content of "the perpetrator-filmed, live-streamed footage of the shootings that was broadcast on Australian television."

"ACMA is also concerned about content made available or linked to on broadcasters' websites. While this is currently beyond its regulatory remit, the ACMA is in close contact with the Australian Press Council as it reviews its members' coverage of the attack."

ACMA chairman Nerida O'Loughlin is writing to the chief executives of commercial, national and subscription broadcasters "requesting urgent information on the nature, extent and timing of the broadcast of content relating to the shootings, in particular from the day of the attack".

On Sunday, Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison called for live-streaming to be suspended on social media after previous guarantees to prevent extremist content on platforms failed again.

New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern will be taking the issue to Facebook and said on Monday "there is more that can and should be done" by the social media giant.

Facebook declined to comment when asked by the Financial Review if it would consider suspending livestreaming.

A News Corp Australia spokesperson said it would give its full cooperation to the ACMA and any other proper inquiry into the coverage of the Christchurch massacre, but noted the free pass given to Facebook.

"We note that the organisations that allowed video of the killings to be streamed live and then failed to remove it from their platforms for many hours are not subject to the same scrutiny and have no formal agreement to take responsibility for their actions," the spokesperson said.

"This goes to the fundamental problem of there being one set of rules for responsible media organisations and no rules at all for digital platforms."

It is not possible to stop Facebook, YouTube and Twitter being used to broadcast horrific events without blocking livestreaming, but social media and security experts believe there are ways to dampen the spread and impact of footage.

UNSW Canberra Cyber director Nigel Phair said banning livestreaming would not work but platforms should be held responsible for content.

"In real time, it's going to be difficult when you look at the amount of minutes being broadcast globally," he said.

"We really need, in the wake of this, and so many other things to start that discussion about what it means to be a good digital citizen ... and pick up our real world sensibilities and put them online. What is it that drives people to do behaviours that they wouldn't do in the real world. We can't legislate our way out of online problems; including this one."

Australian Strategic Policy Institute head of border security and strategic policing John Coyne said banning livestreaming on Facebook would simply mean content would be available on another platform.

"It would be much better for Australians if they didn't feel the need to watch, download, re-post."

Jason Kint, CEO of US trade association Digital Content Next, said governments should be careful when mulling a potential ban on livestreaming. His organisation has urged Facebook, Twitter and Google to invest more resources to reduce the ability for content such as the Christchurch attack to spread via social media so quickly.

"In a sick way it feeds into the goals of the perpetrator ... the way content moves through social media platforms is based on AI or algorithms, and those can be tuned, they can be throttled, slowed down if reputable accounts or news organisations aren't sharing something, then maybe it should be slowed down. They no doubt need to do a better job at relying on the reputation of brands and accounts," he said.

Big tech opportunity

The head of the peak body representing big technology companies across Australia meanwhile said community outrage at the livestreaming of the massacre, marked a chance for the major platforms to demonstrate they have society's best intentions at heart by self regulation.

Australian Information Industry Association CEO Ron Gauci, a former Microsoft, IBM and Telstra executive, said even without the big stick of regulation, he believed Facebook must move to greater regulate content on its platform.

"Our view is that Facebook, like any other media, and information distribution organisation, whether they be traditional press or social media platforms, should be socially responsible in what it allows to be publish and distributed," Mr Gauci said.

"It should equally be subject to complying in conforming with media laws on the matter ... Right now they have an opportunity to exercise some self-regulation in terms of setting its own parameters and its its own manner of conduct, rather than waiting for legislation to govern it."

Mr Gauci said social media platforms had developed technology to filter, monitor and control content, particularly in relation to identifying and removing copyright infringing videos, but that these had proven ineffective in the real time live environment.

While he said he believed Facebook had the best intentions to be socially responsible in removing videos as quickly as possible, it needed to rethink the ability of consumers to post their content live.

"I believe they have technologies available [where] they can buffer content that is posted before it actually gets distributed and maybe there needs to be more diligence in monitoring the content," he said. "Don't we do that with the traditional media with the delay buttons on radio and TV?"

University of Technology Sydney software expert Srinivas Madhisetty said it was beholden on the large technology platforms to do more to help regulators apply society's standards on social media.

He has previously specialised in research into managing privacy of individuals who have their images shared on social media platforms without their consent, and said that existing methods of using artificial intelligence filters to screen content were not effective enough.

"I believe that social media applications should take up the challenge in managing content because these filters fail if the colour temperature changes or it is edited in such a way that it appears like a different video if it is re-shared," Mr Madhisetty said.

"One way of managing the spread of such a videos is to look to use blockchain technology, which can validate that the content is offensive more quickly if multiple users flag it as offensive.

"[As it stands] the best way to stop the livestreaming of offensive content is to implement a time delay, which can check each frame through a AI program to verify it is suitable, but even this is not a 100 per cent accurate."

Telstra meanwhile said late on Monday that it had started temporarily blocking a number of websites that continue to host the footage of the attack.

"We understand this may inconvenience some legitimate users of these sites, but these are extreme circumstances and we feel this is the right thing to do," a spokesperson said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VFV-DW41-JCBD-Y43N-00000-00SOCIAL MEDIA, ETHICS AND REGULATION: ALL YOU NEED TO KNOW2019-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisHOME NEWSSOCIAL MEDIA, ETHICS AND REGULATION: ALL YOU NEED TO KNOWPress Association Reporter

Social media sites should face a compulsory code of ethics in order to tackle harmful or illegal content online, a Commons committee has said.

The report comes after a parliamentary inquiry into fake news by the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee.

Here are some key questions around what it all means.

- What is the fake news inquiry?

MPs began looking into the issue of fake news in 2017 after a rising tide of hoaxers and propagandists spread misinformation on social media, either to push an agenda or make money.

As time went on, the inquiry expanded to investigate wider issues around the effect huge technology companies such as Facebook can have on citizens and society, how some individuals and companies try to manipulate people through social media, and whether Russia had a role in influencing voters in the EU referendum.

MPs from across the House of Commons heard from dozens of academics, executives, political operatives and experts between October 2017 and July 2018 before producing an interim report last year, followed by this final report.

- What does the final report say?

MPs warned that democracy was at risk from the ``malicious and relentless'' targeting of citizens with disinformation and adverts from unidentifiable sources, delivered through social media.

Much of this is directed from agencies working in foreign countries, including Russia, said committee chairman Damian Collins.

He added that big tech companies were failing in the duty of care they owe to their users to act against harmful content, and to respect their data privacy rights.

The report also said electoral law was ``not fit for purpose'' and should be updated to reflect the move to ``microtargeted'' online political campaigning.

Meanwhile, MPs rounded on Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg, who was accused of showing ``contempt'' towards the committee by choosing not to appear before it last year.

- So what does the report recommend?

The committee said ethics guidelines were needed to set out what is and what is not acceptable on social media. The latter includes harmful and illegal content that has been flagged to the platforms by users or identified by the companies themselves.

If tech companies fail to meet their obligations under the code, then an independent regulator should be able to launch legal proceedings against them and have the power to issue large fines, the MPs said.

The committee also called for a comprehensive review of the current rules and regulations surrounding political work during elections and referenda, and separately urged the Government to put pressure on social media companies to publicise instances of disinformation.

- What happens next?

The Government is expected to publish a white paper later this year on proposals to reform laws to make the internet and social media safer.

A Government spokesman said the Culture Secretary would travel to the United States to meet with tech giants including Google, Facebook, Twitter and Apple to discuss many of the issues raised in the report.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V97-3141-JCMN-Y1BX-00000-00Social media firms face ban over suicide images2019-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisSocial media firms face ban over suicide imagesElliott

Jan 27, 2019( The Week UK: http://www.theweek.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) Credits Oli Scarff/AFP/Getty Images Health secretary warns online giants must 'purge' disturbing material or face new legislation or higher taxes One-Minute Read[1] Monday, January 28, 2019 - 6:09am Social media firms could be banned if they fail to remove harmful online content, the health secretary has suggested. See related Fact check: will Mexico pay for Trump's border wall?[2] Is there a plot to smear Robert Mueller?

[3] Matt Hancock has written to social media bosses at Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, Pinterest, Google and Apple warning them to 'purge' material promoting self-harm and suicide to ensure they do not breach the policies of internet providers. It comes just days after the father of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life in 2017 after viewing disturbing content online, said photo-sharing platform Instagram had 'helped' kill his daughter. The girl was found dead in her bedroom after showing 'no obvious signs' of severe mental health issues, only for the family to later discover she had been viewing material on social media linked to anxiety, depression, self-harm and suicide[4]. 'Suicide is now the leading cause of death for young people under 20[5] and levels of self-harm are rising among teenage girls in particular,' Hancock said. Speaking to the BBC[6], Ian Russell criticised tech companies for refusing to give him access to his daughter's accounts so that he could see the content she was looking at in the hours before her death. He also called for the establishment of an independent regulator to ensure that 'distressing content can be removed from social media and online within 24 hours'. The Sunday Times[7] reports that since the interview aired, many more families have come out to accuse technology giants of abetting their children's suicides. Papyrus, a charity that works to prevent youth suicide, said it has been contacted by around thirty families in the past week who believe social media had a part to play in their children's suicides. The Daily Mail[8] reports that Pinterest, which allows users to save images in a virtual scrapbook, 'hosts images of self-harm wounds, fists clasping white pills, and macabre mottos which can be viewed by children aged 13 and over'. The paper also claims that the website, which uses algorithms to drive content, sent a personalised email to Russell containing graphic images a month after she died. Citing the youngster's death, Hancock, the first MP to have his own dedicated app, said in his letter: 'It is appalling how easy it still is to access this content online and I am in no doubt about the harm this material can cause, especially for young people. It is time for internet and social media providers to step up and purge this content once and for all.' He said he wanted to work with internet and social media providers but also threatened to introduce new legislation 'where needed' or impose extra taxes on websites that failed to crack down on disturbing content. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VM7-HV21-JCJY-G3M1-00000-00Social media firms face block on 'harmful' content to prevent 'second Molly Russell'2019-03-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisPOLITICSVersion:2Social media firms face block on 'harmful' content to prevent 'second Molly Russell'By Charles Hymas, Home Affairs Editor and Mike Wright, Social Media Correspondent

Social media firms will be forced to shut down algorithms that promote harmful content to children to prevent a "second Molly Russell," says Britain's data watchdog.

In an interview with The Telegraph, Elizabeth Denham, the information commissioner, said she would not hesitate to use new legal powers to block "addictive" technology which exploited children's data to direct them to "ever more provocative or intensive content."

Molly's father Ian has blamed Instagram for contributing to their 14-year-old daughter's suicide after finding material relating to self-harm, suicide and depression in her account.

Yesterday he backed a statutory duty of care which would hold internet firms to account through regulation with strong sanctions.

"For companies like Instagram, saving a life is as straightforward as changing an algorithm," he said. "To save lives, we must stop this social media suicide storm. This really is a modern-day nightmare."

Banner: Duty of Care

Ms Denham said the way the firms used data to target and personalise services had led to a "ratcheting up" of content delivery to keep children online. That meant material became ever more "addictive and immersive" in a way that was potentially damaging to children's health and well being.

M olly was an example, she said. "A child who is searching for images or even starting to search for articles about depression or finding contacts with other kids that they are suffering from that, the content can become ever more provocative," she said.

"Then children are in on a spiral. Self harm is an example but there is also a lesser understood but important impact that has to do with the commercialisation of our children and their experience online. We need to break that cycle because it is not in the best interests of children.

"Our children have become a bit of a commodity and that is not a value we share in the UK. We don't want our children to be a commodity. The tech companies and services have got away from our values and our laws."

Ms Denham is drawing up a new statutory code, to be published within weeks, which is designed to prevent children accessing content that is inappropriate to their age.

She said she would enforce the code, part of the Government's new data protection legislation, not only through fines of up to 4% of a firm's global turnover - $2 billion for Facebook - but also through  lesser-known "cease and desist" orders which could shut down a tech giant's services.

"We have the power to order a company to stop processing data," she said. "That could be more significant than a fine for a large company that is processing kids' data. And we say it is in contravention of the law and we order a shutdown of a programme that is using kids data."

For the first time, she could also mount "no-notice" inspections, audit algorithms and compel a company to produce information related to any investigation she undertook.

The code will also require the tech firms to enforce age-verification on their sites which would mean no child under 13 would be allowed onto a platform with such an age limit, effectively banning as many as 60% of children who have social media profiles before 13.

She does not plan to specify what technology the firms should use to verify the age of children but she is aiming for 100 per cent coverage: "The sites are not using technology appropriately to be able to monitor the age of people." 

She said the tech giants only tended to change their practices when they faced a "reputational hit" such as the scandal over Molly.

"What needs to happen is sustainable comprehensive regulation so companies are not changing their practice just when something goes wrong but when there is a positive obligation for them to do the right thing in the first place. That's why our children's code is really important," she said.

"When I talk about this positive requirement in law, it means we can say: 'You are delivering this content, how do you know it is appropriate? Show us how you determine it is appropriate for 13 year olds or 16 year olds,'" said Ms Denham.

"We will have the power to do our own investigations and audits. I think the sites are not using technology appropriately to be able to monitor the age of people."

Duty of Care campaign | Read more

The code will also require the firms to protect children's privacy so that all settings are automatically set to private by default with all geo-location also switched off.

"I see our code as protecting kids by first of all requiring appropriate age verification, appropriate consent, minimising the collection of personal data to what is relevant to deliver the service, limiting the sharing to third parties and putting in place privacy friendly defaults," said Ms Denham.

She also backed The Telegraph's campaign for a statutory duty of care, saying it was "positive" because it placed a proactive responsibility on the tech giants to combat online harms and to develop processes that could achieve that.

Speaking at a parliamentary event for a statutory duty of care, which has been demanded by The Daily Telegraph and NSPCC, Mr Russell described the day he and his wife, Janet, found Molly just six days before her 15th birthday.

"I remember Janet's scream," said Mr Russell. "I remember pushing past her as she came out of Molly's bedroom.

"I remember my disbelief when I saw my lifeless, youngest daughter; the moment my old life stopped - and a new, emptier life started."

Following her death, Mr Russell discovered Molly had been looking at "sickening" self-harm and suicide content on Instagram, Pinterest and YouTube, which he said helped "persuade [Molly] that she was worthless."

After hearing Mr Russell speak, the Digital Minister Margot James said she wanted social media companies to make child safety "front and centre" of their considerations rather than "just finding ways of building traffic".

She added: "It has convinced me in government that we have a duty to act in ways that will compel as well as encourage companies to put the protection of children and the security of users at the heart of their corporate culture".

The NSPCC's chief executive, Peter Wanless, said the charity wanted social media companies to introduce "special protections" for any account held by an under-18 on their platforms.

He added: "The need for this sort of regulation is undeniable. It is needed urgently to hold social networks to account."

Baroness Kidron, whose amendments to the laws brought about the code, said: "We're calling time on big tech calling the shots. This should be a sea change that will make a huge difference to protecting children online."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y7G-0BM1-JDJN-606C-00000-00Social media firms 'have to act against fake news effectively'2020-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisSocial media firms 'have to act against fake news effectively'

Panellists at the discussion. PICTURE: Shaji Kayamkulam

Joseph Varghese

Social media organisations and companies have to act effectively in curtailing or stopping any hate posts by removing them instantly and ensure that their platforms are not used for such purposes, experts said at a panel discussion on the second and concluding day of an international conference yesterday.


The International Conference on 'Social Media: Challenges and Ways to Promote Freedoms and Protect Activists' organised by the National Human Rights Committee discussed the social media challenges and freedom of expression at a working group session titled 'Regulating Big Tech - Transparency and Accountability in Content Moderation'.
The panellists at the session said some responsibilities and supervision of the content moved from countries to companies. They also pointed out that the social media companies have their own agenda and drag the people into them. The session was moderated by Nazila Ghanea, professor at University of Oxford, UK, while the rapporteur for the session was Iris de Villars, head of Tech Desk, Reporters Without Borders, Paris.
Senior political adviser of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in the EU, Matilda Sisatto, examined the impact of social media and various applications on human life and highlighted the importance of e-privacy.
"E-privacy regulates online movement as well as offline movement. Social media intelligence must ensure the privacy of activists to lead a normal life while making sure that disinformation is rooted out effectively," she said .
She also noted that although these applications and websites have made it easy for people to see their important matters, they have become at the same time a way to monitor people and collect data about them. Jillian York, director of the International Freedom of Expression, Electronic Frontier Foundation, noted that some governments and social media companies deliberately ignore civil society organisations in many of the agreements between the two sides.
York pointed out that governments always have problems that they seek to confront on social media, such as extremism, terrorism and hate speech, but some of them deal with these issues as technical issues although they are societal rather than technical problems.
She also noted that after years of monitoring and supervision by governments on social media to face many societal problems, the result was negative, as it was unable to provide solutions to these problems, confirming that many governments and social media companies participate in repression through the Internet.
The repression is carried out through legislation enacted by governments with companies to limit freedom of expression.
Jerald Joseph, commissioner of the National Human Rights Commission of Malaysia, stressed the importance of working to change laws dating back to colonial times and called on governments to respect human rights and freedom of expression for which activists are being prosecuted.
Joseph said that companies, in turn, are called upon to respect human rights, noting the need to co-operate with the government side in order to make progress on these levels.
Social media expert in Taiwan and East Asia, Michel Shia, said some countries have used electronic applications to monitor their citizens, while others have used them to counter false and fabricated news issued against them.
Fernand de Varennes, UN Special Rapporteur on Minority Issuse, pointed to the high level of hatred towards minorities in recent years through social media platforms, and noted that there are major challenges in this area, which the international community must raise to reduce the level of hatred.
He explained that three quarters of hate in social media is directed against minorities.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RNT-S931-F021-639Y-00000-00Social media for six-year-olds? Facebook is spying on your kids;The tech giant has paid researchers to endorse its 'child-friendly' apps2018-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Social media for six-year-olds? Facebookis spying on your kidsThe tech giant has paid researchers to endorse its 'child-friendly' appsDanny Fortson

Josh Golin was shocked. For nearly a year, the founder of the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood, had been talking to Facebookabout how the social media giant deals with children using its platform. Then, one Friday in December, he got a call: on the following Monday, Facebookwas going to release a new product called FacebookMessenger Kids, a standalone app specifically crafted for children as young as six.

Golin found the news difficult to comprehend. "It was a bolt from the blue," he recalled. "Given that we did have a dialogue, it was a surprise it was not mentioned to me until it was a fait accompli."

Child development experts, campaigners and parent groups were outraged. Golin organised a letter signed by 100 paediatricians and child psychologists demanding Facebookwithdraw the app immediately. "Younger children are simply not ready to have social media accounts," the letter said.

Facebookdid not respond to the letter, though it says it has begun to reach out to signatories. In the meantime, it has doubled down. While the first version of the app was only for Apple products, the $520bn (£370bn) giant last week launched Messenger Kids for Android, the operating system of most mobiles and tablets. Also, it emerged that the independent child development experts who had "co-developed" the app had received funding from Facebook, raising questions over the rigour employed to create a product aimed at the most vulnerable section of the population.

Facebook's assault on children may - along with Russia's election tampering - finally convince regulators to turn on Silicon Valley after years of lax oversight.

A growing body of research suggests social media can severely damage youngsters' psychological development. Half of US teens feel addicted to their mobile devices, according to the non-profit organisation Common Sense Media.

A study of 13 and 14-year-olds by the psychologist Jean Twenge, author of iGen, a highly critical book about tech-obsessed teens, found that heavy users are 56% more likely to say they are unhappy and 35% are more likely to have a risk factor for suicide.

Thus far the industry has reacted with a collective shrug. In October, Google announced that its Home voice assistant was now the first such device with the ability to understand and interact with children as soon as they are able to speak. YouTube Kids, launched three years ago, has aired doctored cartoons showing characters dying or committing other disturbing acts. Snapchat is designed for children at least 13 years old but its verification system is regularly gamed.

And now Facebookis getting in on the act. Golin said: "Mark Zuckerberg has vowed to do better and we said, 'Wow, what an easy, straightforward way to show you mean that, by saying kids' wellbeing is more important than market share.' They did the opposite."

For now the app is available only in America. Depending on the outcome of the battle unfolding there, it could soon be rolled out in Britain and beyond.

Messenger Kids - access to which is controlled by parents - has been billed as a safe, ad-free place for children to chat and send pictures. At the app's unveiling, Facebookname-checked the National Parent Teacher Association, military family support network Blue Star Families and a participant in research conducted by New Mexico State University's Learning Games Lab, all of which it said had helped shape the app's features and safeguards. Boston-based Golin and other vocal Facebookcritics were cut out of that process.

Yet it emerged last week that most of the partner organisations had received funding from Facebook. The National PTA confirmed it had received money from the company for the first time last year, but said it "did not play a role in the development of the Messenger Kids app". That contradicted statements this weekend from Facebook, which said the PTA was the only organisation that received funding directly related to the app's development. It added, however, that this amounted to "pizza money". Facebookalso funded New Mexico State University's research.

The company said it had been "transparent" about its relationships with the organisations, adding: "We sometimes provide funding to cover programmatic or logistics expenses, to make sure our work together can have the most impact." Golin had a different take: "They stacked the deck so they got the answers they knew they were going to get."

Ten days ago, politicians, tech industry exiles and academics came together in Washington DC to begin the fightback. The event marked the launch of Truth About Tech, a campaign to force tech giants to make their products less addictive and to warn children via materials distributed at America's 55,000 public schools, about the risks of social media.

The campaign is being led by Common Sense Media and the Centre for Humane Technology, a non-profit organisation set up by Tristan Harris, the former Google design ethicist who has become one of the most prominent critics of Silicon Valley.

There have been previous panics about such things as rock'n'roll and television, but Harris argues this is different: mobile phones are immensely more powerful objects, are always with us and are packed with apps designed to addict.

"When you open up that blue Facebookicon, you have just opened up a supercomputer that's playing chess against your mind, seeing 50m moves ahead, figuring out, 'What move can I play, what story can I show you, that perfectly gets you to engage?' " he said. "On the other side, we're still living inside of Evolution 1.0 hardware, which is your mind. There's no world where this is going to end well for us. It's like bringing a knife to a space-laser fight. It's not good for us and it's not good for kids."

The pursuit of children may be disconcerting, but from a business perspective it is logical - particularly for Facebook. The company this month revealed its first-ever quarterly decline in users in its core markets of America and Canada, though globally it is still growing strongly. In Britain, it is set to see an 8% drop this year in teenage users up to the age of 17, who are shifting to rival Snapchat, according to research firm eMarketer. Analyst Bill Fisher said: "Facebookhas a teen problem."

What better way to refill the pipeline than to lure in kids between 6 and 12? Facebooksaid it will not "migrate" children to its main site when they turn 13 - the legal minimum age in America at which they can sign up to online services. Yet bringing them into its ecosystem breeds familiarity, increasing the likelihood they will stay once they are of age.

The problem is that the core of the entire bargain is attention, and attention is captured through algorithms that serve up content to keep people swiping and tapping. Sean Parker, the billionaire investor who was Facebook's first president, recently said it exploits "a vulnerability in human psychology". James Steyer, founder of Common Sense Media, said: "Tech companies are conducting a massive, real-time experiment on our kids and, at present, no one is really holding them accountable."

In December, the Westminster government agreed to an amendment to the Data Protection Bill, based on child- protection proposals put forward by Baroness (Beeban) Kidron. The bill is part of the EU's impending data privacy legislation, expected to have far-reaching consequences for Europe's tech firms.

It is not just social media companies coming under pressure. The hedge fund Jana Partners and California State Teachers' Retirement System, one of the largest pension funds, last month urged Apple to build new controls into its devices to make it easier for parents to control usage.

The average child gets their first phone at the age of 10 and uses it for an average of 4.5 hours a day. The two funds, both Apple investors, pointed out that 9 out of 10 parents try to curb screen time.

"It is both unrealistic and a poor long-term business strategy to ask parents to fight this battle alone," they said.Why 13 is the magic numberOnce an American child turns 13, the online floodgates open. They can sign up for services without their parents' knowledge; companies can bombard them with ads; protections vanish. Why? It dates back to 2000, when the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (Coppa) became law.

The world was a very different place back then. The Nasdaq had just reached its peak before the dotcom crash and only a few hundred million people were online. It would be another seven years before the first iPhone was released. Mark Zuckerberg was still at high school, just weeks from turning 16.

Coppa made collecting data on the under-13s so onerous that the industry, broadly, left kids alone. For most companies, it did not much matter - the internet was just not that big or accessible, and most were still trying to figure out basic ecommerce. Today, more than 3bn smartphones put the web within reach at all times. The average age at which a child gets their first phone is 10. Social media has taken a central role in the lives of many.

Both children's rights campaigners and big tech want Coppa replaced, but for very different reasons. Campaigners want protections to extend beyond 13. Industry wants to reach kids sooner. It is one of many battles likely to flare up this year.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y90-4BR1-JCH9-G2BG-00000-00Social media free speech in Africa (2)2020-02-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisSocial media free speech in Africa (2)

Stengel's description of how Russia's Internet Research Agency (IRA) works provides insights into alternative but likely more effective strategies for fighting online disinformation. "Every day, in two shifts, a few hundred young people spend their time writing blog posts, tweets, Facebook posts, Vkontakte posts and much moreit is indeed a factory they manufacture thousands upon thousands of pieces of pro-Russian, anti-American content a day.

" Although the Russian IRA is owned by a businessman allied to the Russian government, every government should probably have an IRA-type outfit much like most governments have their own news agencies and broadcasters.The suggestion is not that a government-owned social media agency should engage in some of the negative activities Russia's IRA is accused of.

Still, such an agency would probably be the more appropriate public bulwark against the purveyors of fake news and disinformation on social media. It is certainly a better proposition than the potentially free-speech stifling social media regulations being proposed by some African governments and in fact already in practice in Singapore and elsewhere.

That said, some regulation of social media has clearly become necessary. The key would be for any regulation to be geared towards incentivizing accurate news reportage.

In other words, new media practitioners should be made to have as much fear of punishment as their counterparts in old media. To succeed, the active cooperation of big tech would be required.

But would they choose to be part of the solution?In practice, considering the robust political lobbying apparatus of American big tech firms, this would be a herculean task. But if African governments and others truly desire a curb on disinformation, it would not be untoward for them to be part of a global effort towards forcing the US Congress' hand, via the United NationsMake platforms liable for their contentSocial media platforms are probably conflicted.

That is, if you infer correctly from Harvard professor Shoshana Zuboff's 2019 book The Age of Surveillance Capitalism: The fight for a human future at the new frontier of power, where she asserts "fake news and other forms of information corruption have been perennial features of Google and Facebook's online environments[with]countless examples of disinformation that survived and even thrived because it fulfilled economic imperatives". Stengel corroborates this view: "The players in this conflict are assisted by the big social media platforms, which benefit just as much from the sharing of content that is false as content that is true.

" Even more bluntly, Stengel asserts "popularity is the measure [social media platforms] care about, not accuracy or truthfulness." Still, as Zuboff adds, "they [Facebook and others] absolutely have the tools to shut down fake news".

But they have to be willed to do so conscientiously. And there is evidence they do so when prompted by governments.

Still, in America, where most of the top global social media platforms are headquartered, there is limited incentive for them to combat disinformation. Their complacency stems from the United States' Communications Decency Act (CDA) of 1996 which provides immunity to social media platforms from being liable for published content.

The part of particular interest in that American legislation reads thus: "No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider." Were this part of the legislation to be modified, it is well-known these platforms are perfectly capable of policing mischievous content with super efficiency.

Thus, incentivising them via liability for disinformation might be ideal.In practice, considering the robust political lobbying apparatus of American big tech firms, this would be a herculean task.

But if African governments and others truly desire a curb on disinformation, it would not be untoward for them to be part of a global effort towards forcing the US Congress' hand, via the United Nations perhaps not that that has ever successfully forced the Americans to do anything they didn't want to do towards such a modification. Even so, Stengel sees a way to make changes to the legislation that may likely be acceptable to social media platforms: "One way to do this is to revise the language of the CDA to say that no platform that makes a good faith effort to fulfil its responsibility to delete harmful content and provide information to users about that content can be liable for the damage that it does.

" Still, Stengel adds, "for all this to work, we need global privacy regulations, a universal definition of disinformation and legal consequences for purveying it."In any case, Singapore is pushing ahead with fighting fake news on its own albeit it could be argued its intentions are not entirely altruistic.

In November 2019, for instance, the Singaporean government ordered Facebook to issue a disclaimer ("Facebook is legally required to tell you that the Singapore government says this post has false information") on a post by a local newspaper that it considered inaccurate. But how many of these orders can it issue? Its progress in this regard is likely to be incremental.

A global effort, with America in the lead, under the auspices of the United Nations, would likely be more effective. In the absence of such a global coalition, hard-fought democratic gains around the world would be increasingly eroded especially in the poor parts of the world, like Africa, where they are mostly needed.

Rafiq Raji
