Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XCX-5PV1-JB20-G42C-00000-00Social Media Giant Out with Quarterly Earnings Today; Horowitz's New Book Outlines Corporate Culture; Facebook Facing Pushback Over Libra and Privacy; October ADP Report; Jeffrey Epstein Autopsy, Doctor: Death Shows Signs Of Homicide; Muilenburg To Appear Before House Panel; Nats Force World Series Game 7; Apple Earnings Preview; 3Q GDP Beats Expectations; College Athlete Compensation NCAA: Students Can "Benefit" From Use Of Names, Images; Former Secretary Of State Rex Tillerson Arrives ExxonMobil Climate Change Trial2019-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTBen Horowitz, Lee Carter, Omeed Malik, Kevin O'Leary, Stephanie Pomboy, Jack BrewerNEWSFinancial103003cb.231Social Media Giant Out with Quarterly Earnings Today; Horowitz's New Book Outlines Corporate Culture; Facebook Facing Pushback Over Libra and Privacy; October ADP Report; Jeffrey Epstein Autopsy, Doctor: Death Shows Signs Of Homicide; Muilenburg To Appear Before House Panel; Nats Force World Series Game 7; Apple Earnings Preview; 3Q GDP Beats Expectations; College Athlete Compensation NCAA: Students Can "Benefit" From Use Of Names, Images; Former Secretary Of State Rex Tillerson Arrives ExxonMobil Climate Change TrialMaria Bartiromo, Susan Li, Cheryl Casone, Lauren Simonetti, Gerri Willis, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, October 30th. Your top stories right now, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The U.S. economy in focus this morning. We are getting the first look of the labor market with the ADP report coming out in less than 15 minutes. The estimate is for 120,000 jobs added to the economy in the month of October. We are 15 minutes away from that. Plus, after that, we'll get a look at the first look at the third quarter GDP, that's in 30 minutes' time.

We're expecting growth of 1.6 percent for the GDP for the third quarter, and that'll be out shortly, as well. And then, we're on the countdown mode to the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. We are expecting the Fed to cut rates by a quarter point today. That would be the third cut this year, and we're expecting that, today, at 2:00 p.m. Eastern.

Earnings season, meanwhile, rolling on in the midst of all of that. General Electric out this morning, with the double beat. CEO Larry Culp says that he remains confident that it will unlock value for G.E. shareholders as its transformation accelerates. The stock is up this morning, almost seven percent right now.

Technology, of course, is in focus after the close, Apple and Facebook are set to report earnings. We will tell you what you need to know, coming up, ahead of those numbers, as we await the Fed decision and the GDP. Futures this morning, are mixed. Dow Futures are down 5 points, the S&P Futures right now, up 1 point, and the NASDAQ Futures up 11-1/2.

The S&P hit a new intraday high yesterday, before retreating and snapping a four-day winning streak. The Dow and the NASDAQ also finished slightly lower, on the session, as you can see there.

Global markets look like this, this morning, take a look at the FT 100, which is actually higher right now, 3 points, the CAC Quarante is up 13 points, and the DAX Index in Germany is lower by 28.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board, take a look, fractional moves, pretty much across the board. The Shanghai Composite down one-half of one percent, ahead of what we are expecting to be a deal with China, signed, in the next month, we'll see about that, continued mixed signals there.

Our top story this hour, are the earnings on technology, Facebook, for example, the social media giant out with its third quarter numbers after the bell tonight. Estimates show earnings of $1.91 a share, with revenue of $17.37 billion. This coming as the social media giant is under fire over privacy and antitrust concerns.

Joining me right now is the founder Andreessen Horowitz -- the co-founder of Andreessen Horowitz and author of the new book, What You Do is Who You Are, and he is Ben Horowitz. Ben, it's great to have you. Thanks so much for joining us.

BEN HOROWITZ, FO-FOUNDER, ANDREESSEN HOROWITZ: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So, let me kick off with Facebook, you're obviously an early investor, you were an early investor in Facebook. Tell us about your take on the company today, as you've watched it grow from this small unicorn to where it is today.

HOROWITZ: Yes, you know, my partner, Marc's on the board, said I will be careful, I'm not going to do any forecasting on it or anything like that. But, yes -- I mean, look, it started out, and this is one of the things that's interesting about watching it the whole way.

You know, it starts out, and it's a social network, and it's a way to share pictures with your friends and so forth, and now, they're under fire about like who's going to win the election. So, like, it's quite a transformation and an amazing -- the company itself is only 15 years old.

BARTIROMO: Do you expect now that these companies have -- and you guys, you and Marc Andreessen have been so, you know, prescient on this, and the student of what's taken place for the last 20 years, really.

Are you surprised at what has taken place that today, we're talking about these companies, and not necessarily just Facebook, that they are more powerful than they ever have been before? What do you think in terms of their size and power?

HOROWITZ: Look, I think it surprised everybody just how important it became so fast, and how like what it means to have 2 billion users have become an international company with an international user base, and people are communicating in ways they never have.

In particular, I think, in Facebook's case, you have a public square with kind of social norms that's a thousand people that we used to have, and now it's 2 billion people.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

HOROWITZ: And the norms don't work, and you know, people don't obey them anyway. And so, what do we, you know, like -- and then it's an international community, it's not a U.S. community, and so it's kind of a situation we have not faced before.

BARTIROMO: So, do you expect that we will see a bigger regulatory hand at some point, for these companies, given now that they're under fire for privacy breaches, and now, you know, you've got people like congressional, people like Devin Nunes, suing Twitter for, you know, censoring Conservative speech, Tulsi Gabbard is suing Google for the same reason.

HOROWITZ: Yes, absolutely. Look, I think that people are -- you know, people are up in arms, and I think that they are misinterpreting like what's possible, a little bit, like, you know, when I read it, it sounds like, you know, like we can just roll back the clock on technology and stop social media.

Well, now, like even if you like blew up Facebook or whatever, like, social media is still going to be there, you know, it's probably going to be in the form of Tencent or, you know, a company where you really don't have regulatory control.

So, I think you have to be kind of measured and how you think about how we get to the future. And then, also, I think, look, it's a systems problem, it's not a good versus evil.

Mark Zuckerberg is probably the most earnest committed CEO in technology, and you know, he hasn't taken a salary, I think, in like a decade, and he hasn't taken any new stock options. He's not doing it for his personal gain. He really does want Facebook to be the right thing.

So, I think, that, you know, the correct way to approach, is to understand that we're talking about a new phenomenon here.

BARTIROMO: I think people -- I think people agree with you on that, I mean, that's the way he came across in the testimony, by the way. Last week, we just saw pictures of him walking in the testimony. How do you see China? I'm glad you mentioned Tencent.

How do you see China in the face of all of this? Because on the one hand, we know that this is an enormous growth opportunity. You've got 1.4 billion people in China --

HOROWITZ: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- and American companies want to get there, you know, their exposure there, and they want to expose to that -- to that huge market.

And at the same time, you've got rules in China, and this is a Communist country, and they're tracking their citizens, and they're using facial recognition to do that, and you're being forced to change the search engine if you're Google, or change the way you do business to, you know, appease the Chinese Communists.

HOROWITZ: Yes. Well, Daryl Morey, I mean, got a big taste of that, Daryl Morey, not a tweet, a retweet, which immediately deleted and --

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

HOROWITZ: -- like -- and you see the, like, fury of the reaction, so it's not something, like, where you used to hear. And, in fact, China employs more people to surveil and spends more money surveilling their own people than they do on national defense.

So, it's a very, very different view of how you run a society. And, I think, you know, one thing that we have to consider is, if our tools, if our platforms for communicate like, we hamstring them, and kind of shut down those companies, or defeat those -- our own companies.

Then the companies we're going to be using are the Chinese products. And those rules are not rules, that I think anybody here is going to like.

BARTIROMO: Marc Andreessen, years ago, was famous for saying, software will eat everything, right? I mean --

HOROWITZ: Yes. Unfortunately, he was right about that.

BARTIROMO: And he was right about that because there's a software product for every industry, every company, and that's where a lot of the growth has been in the private market as well. You see so many things across your desk. Let's talk about this because it's been --

HOROWITZ: Sure.

BARTIROMO: -- a bit of a roller coaster year for IPOs, with these valuations where they are in the private market. Are things getting excessive in terms of evaluation? How do you value what you are seeing and where, in particular, I want to really get this from you, where do you see the growth in the -- in the private market at this point?

HOROWITZ: Yes. So, you know, like I'm not one to, kind of, speculate on whether we are in a bubble or not in a bubble --

BARTIROMO: Sure.

HOROWITZ: -- I can't say that, and the other -- I mean, like, I think that, you know, historically, the tech multiples are not -- it's not like 1999, so, you know, having been CEO in 1999, I remember what that was, and those were off the charts. These are not off the charts.

In terms of growth in the private sector, it's actually very interesting. So, one of the fastest growing sectors is this Fintech, what we call Fintech. And that's kind of driven by a few things, one is that, you know, the trust that consumers had in banks, just really waned after the 2009 crisis.

So, if you look at, like the younger cohorts, somebody say 20 to 25-years- old, they probably don't have a credit card, they don't trust banks, they don't trust, kind of, that whole system.

And so, the good news, you know, for new companies is that creates an opportunity for them to go grab consumers in a way that you couldn't have before with new products, with products that don't charge exorbitant hidden fees and interest rates in these kinds of --

BARTIROMO: Is that why you see things like Apple money and, you know, all these tech companies are trying to come out with financial products.

HOROWITZ: No, absolutely. So, and I think that, you know, almost in many companies that we see are becoming Fintech companies, I think we just, you know -- Uber kind of moved into that direction the other day.

BARTIROMO: That's right. Exactly.

HOROWITZ: And I think we are going to see a lot more of that for sure.

BARTIROMO: You wrote a book, it's a new book titled, What You Do is Who You Are. It speaks focus on the corporate world and how executives can help build a culture that can weather any storm, socially or financially, apropos for today's climate, where you've got the business roundtable coming out and saying, look, shareholders are not the only ones important, you know, in fact, stakeholders are more important.

Tell me why you wrote the book and the point you are trying to make here.

HOROWITZ: Well, look, you know, there's a lot of criticism of how companies are run these days and so forth, but, like what I find in my work is that, nobody like the tools to how you build a culture, are not really that well-articulated.

And in particular, like it's very hard because you are talking about how people behave when you're not there, when you're not looking, right? Do they show up to meetings on time? Do they return a phone call? Do they -- you know, when they're doing a business deal, is it optimized for the price or for the partnership? Like, what are all these behaviors?

They're not your KPIs or your mission statement and those kinds of things, and how you move that and shape that overtime, it has to be really complex. And the bigger the company is, and the faster it grows, the more complicated it is. So, I thought that there was a real need to just help people with those issues.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, at this point, what do company CEOs need to understand better? Do you think it's what we were talking about, in terms of the business roundtable, that it's not just about money?

HOROWITZ: You know -- I think that gets overstretched, you know, we have gotten to this world where it's like Shakespearean good versus evil.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOROWITZ: Like, something bad happened, you know, that's a bad CEO and so forth, but like, there really is much more kind of Greek tragedy, humans against the gods. And like, the gods are the system, and the systems get very, very complex when you get 2 billion people, on a social network, and these kinds of things.

And so, you know, the thing that I try to help with the book is like, how do we make the system better --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOROWITZ: -- as opposed to, you know, how do we cut somebody's head off.

BARTIROMO: I love the fact that you said that Fintech is one of the hottest areas of growth, right now, because we are also talking about Libra, with Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, defending the cryptocurrency in a congressional hearing last week. What do you --

HOROWITZ: Sure.

BARTIROMO: How should our viewers look at Libra versus other currencies versus the crypto world?

HOROWITZ: Yes. So, let's start with a problem that Libra aims to solve. So, you know, Facebook would like to have payments and money in their social networking system. It'd be very convenient for users.

You can do, you know, all kinds of things, you know, with good friends you often exchange money with, and so forth. But money has a problem, traditional money, that it doesn't scale beyond a country boundary.

And so, the idea with Libra is that you have, kind of, a way to do, kind of, payments and money exchange --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOROWITZ: -- that is international. They're doing it in a way using a new technology, known as cryptocurrency, which basically is a software that's not necessarily owned by a company.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOROWITZ: It's just a kind of an open source service.

BARTIROMO: It's fascinating --

HOROWITZ: And you can trust the code.

BARTIROMO: -- what's taking place. Ben, it's great to have you. Thank you.

HOROWITZ: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Ben Horowitz joining us. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The October ADP report due out in moment. Economists are expecting an increase of jobs of 120,000 private sector jobs added to the economy in the month of October. This ADP report often gives us an insight into what we're going to expect for the Labor Department report. The Labor Department report is out on Friday, similar expectations. Although, don't forget, you had a G.M. strike, you had a Boeing situation, 125,000 is the number on ADP. Let's get right to Lauren Simonetti with more on that. Looks like it's fractionally better than expected, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, a little bit better than expected. 120,000 was the expectation, came in at 125,000. But look at the trend, Maria, in September, 135,000. In August 157,000. So, we are seeing job gains slow down a little bit. Of course, this could be looked at as a precursor to the big October jobs report from the government expected to show 85,000 jobs added in the month of October. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right, markets are pretty steady on the heels of this number. We're still looking at a mixed open for the -- for the broader averages. Look, this is slightly better than expected. Kevin, what are your thoughts on the ADP number here and what it might tell us about the October situation?

KEVIN O'LEARY, ENTREPRENEUR & CHAIRMAN, O'SHARES ETFS: Single job prints generally don't move markets, Maria, you need three in a row to show a trend. I think we'll see pretty good stability and continue to be under four percent unemployment. You know, these are kind of micro reports you detailed all the different issues we have to deal with in this sprint. But jobs right now are looked at. We're full employment in America.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

O'LEARY: Period. And things are going quite well in the domestic economy.

BARTIROMO: Omeed?

OMEED MALIK, FOUNDER AND CEO, FARVAHAR PARTNERS: One thing I point out, though, is on GDP. I think it's coming for the last two quarters in a row. That's the first time that's happened since around a recession. So, again, you're -- I totally agree with you, holistically. It's just something to be aware of. But there are so many headwinds that could be solved very quickly if we do get some of these deals done.

O'LEARY: Yes, you need to print below 1.7 on GDP before anybody really be concerned about recession. To me, it's the politics versus the investment environment.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: That's right.

MALIK: Yes.

O'LEARY: I don't see a recession going into the election. And therefore, I want to stay long equities.

MALIK: Yes.

O'LEARY: That's the way I look at it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And, of course, you got a president in the White House, Lee, who wants this market to go up and the economy to do well. You got to believe he's going to do whatever it takes to make sure that that is steady.

CARTER: I mean, there's no question about it. Whenever the market seems to start reacting about trade, the President reacts. There's absolutely no question this President is committed to this economy. And the other thing I think that is really important right now that people need to keep in mind is that the more the Democrats (INAUDIBLE) against the economy by saying the recession is coming, this economy really isn't working, it doesn't necessarily look good for them. And I also think that people are hearing a little bit of the boy who cried wolf, is it ever really going to happen? I think people are more and more seeing that these numbers are coming out. Things are feeling good. We are at record low unemployment. People in small businesses and local communities can't even find, you know -- can't even find people to work.

O'LEARY: It's a remarkable expansion. And you have to hand it to the policy. They deregulated the economy at a time that it was coil like a spring. It's not just tax reform, it's deregulation at the state and federal level.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

O'LEARY: It's getting this small business environment to keep expanding.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

O'LEARY: It's been a wonderful time to be an investor. So, whether you like Trump or you don't, the policy is what's working.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. All right. Well, he definitely moved the needle on economic growth with the deregulation and the tax cuts, but does he take that away? Does he wind that back down with the trade uncertainty?

O'LEARY: I think what we'll get is a slow increase towards a real I.P. and access to the Chinese market deal.

BARTIROMO: Which is important.

O'LEARY: And that is going to accelerate S&P earnings. I think it could be as worth -- as worth as much as a 15-percent increase on equity values if we actually had a deal.

BARTIROMO: If you get a deal, you think the market goes up 15 percent?

O'LEARY: Yes, I do.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because I guess it was Art Laffer who said, look, get ready for Dow 30,000 if we get a China deal. Do you want to say something real quick?

MALIK: I'll just say, Kevin, I don't see any deregulation in the state of California, though. That's the opposite.

O'LEARY: Yes, that's not really America.

MALIK: OK. I just wanted to confirm.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: They think they're not America, actually. They think they can make their own rules in California. We'll talk about that. We are going to take a break. When we come back, big tech on tap. Apple gears up to report earnings after the bell tonight. We're going to take you live to Cupertino, California, get a preview of the items analysts are watching in the Apple quarter. Plus, pain is temporary, but a homerun catch? It is forever. How Bud Light is commending one ultimate fan who sacrificed his bones to save his beers, that's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A bombshell claim in the Jeffrey Epstein death investigation. Cheryl Casone with the details now and headlines. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: So, Maria, Dr. Michael Baden, the former New York City medical examiner on "FOX & FRIENDS" earlier this morning cast a doubt on the official cause of death of Jeffrey Epstein, the disgrace financier and sex offender.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. MICHAEL BADEN, FORMER NYC MEDICAL EXAMINER: I think that the evidence points toward homicide rather than suicide.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Why?

BADEN: Because there are multiple three fractures in the hyoid bone, the thyroid cartilage that are very unusual for suicide and more indicative of strangulation, homicidal strangulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, Epstein was found dead in his New York City prison cell back in August. He was facing trial on federal sex trafficking charges involving underage girls.

Well, Boeing's CEO is set to get back on the hot seat on Capitol Hill today. Dennis Muilenburg going to appear before the House Transportation Committee. That's going to be later this morning 10:00 a.m. Eastern Time. Muilenburg was grilled by lawmakers yesterday in a Senate hearing over the deadly 737 Max crashes that killed almost 400 people. Families of the victims held up photos of their loved ones during that testimony. An emotional day for a lot of those families.

Well, let's switch gears and talk a little baseball, folks. The World Series is headed to Game 7 after the Washington Nationals beat the Houston Astros 7-2. The game wasn't without a controversy though when Nationals shortstop Trea Turner was called out when the umpire ruled that he interfered with the first baseman. This is the first time in postseason history that the road team has won the first six games in the best of seven series. And then remember this guy, Nat superfan Jeff Adams? He is now the star of his very own Bud Light commercial. This, of course, Maria, is the guy that we couldn't stop watching. He stopped the home run ball without dropping his two beers. The beer company also hooked him up with seats and travel to last night's game in Houston. Game 7 tonight. Box first pitch at 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time.

(LAUGHTER)

CASONE: By the way, he has a huge bruise on his chest.

BARTIROMO: I can imagine that ball was going fast.

CASONE: Yes. (INAUDIBLE) big bruise. He's like, yes, it's still there. So -- but he saved the beers, so ...

BARTIROMO: He did.

CARTER: My hero.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl. That Jeffrey Epstein story is pretty significant as well. We'll be talking about that. We want to look ahead though to Apple earnings. The technology giant reporting fourth quarter results after the bell tonight. Investors are looking at the iPhone sales and the popularity of the wearable devices. Susan Li with the preview now of what's to expect in Cupertino. Hi, Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. That's right, the biggest company in the world, bigger than Microsoft, now hitting a record, of course recently reported results after the bell and that usually moves in the last report cards that we've gotten. So, we're expecting a drop in profit for Apple later on today. But this quarter, the quarter that they reporting does include 10 days of iPhone 11 sales. And we know that in several outlets, including the Nikkei News has reported that Apple has had to increase its production in order to meet the -- what they say is overwhelming and exciting demand right now for the iPhone.

The iPhone still makes up 54 percent, 54 percent of Apple sales, so we know that they've been transitioning, shifting to more services with the Apple TV+ streaming service debuting this Friday, November the 1st, also wearable since they are now selling these new AirPod Pro starting today, as well. Hopefully, we'll get some more clarity in terms of how well they're doing, and are they making up for the transition in slowing iPhone sales. And something else that we're watching closely are tariffs, the U.S.-China trade tariffs given that we are looking at iPhones and iPads, possibly facing 15 percent of tariffs starting on December the 15th. That's something that we'll be hearing from Tim Cook hopefully on the earnings call AirPods and have been already subject to tariffs starting in September.

And just a reminder to you, Maria, that we will be speaking to Tim Cook himself and also Luca Maestri CFO for their thoughts on earnings later on today. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Susan, that's great. Thank you so much. These exclusives coming up today. Susan Li. Coming up, we are awaiting the advanced reading on the third-quarter GDP. Economists are forecasting economic growth of 1.6 percent. The number right after the break. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, October 30th. We have breaking news this morning of the U.S. economy. In just a few moments, we will get the first look at third-quarter GDP. We are expecting a growth rate of 1.6 percent for the third quarter. The numbers will be out momentarily. Market right now are flat going into it as we await GDP, we are also looking ahead to this afternoon's Federal Reserve decision. The end of a two-day Fed meeting happens today at 2:00 and we're expecting a cut in interest rates at about 2:15 p.m. Eastern.

Going into all of that, the DowIndustrials are down nine points, the S&P is up a half a point, and the NASDAQ is up 9 -- up 1.9 percent is the number, it's better-than-expected. Right to Lauren Simonetti we go --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- with this better-than-expected GDP, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: All right. Keep your an eye on the markets to see how it reacts to this better-than-expected number. So, the first read that we're getting for how fast the economy grew in the third quarter is 1.9 percent, that's better-than-expected. We were expecting 1.6 percent. But it's slower than what we had, two percent in the second quarter and 3.1 percent in the first quarter.

So this, like I said, is better than expected, but look at the numbers on your screen, they're not moving, because the question now investors are asking is what does Jay Powell and the Federal Reserve do with this data?

We saw in the -- in the ADP report that, yes, job growth continues, but manufacturing is a weak spot. So, they have to weigh stronger consumer spending with weak manufacturing, and figure out does the economy deserve or need a third rate cut for 2019. So, it seems like the economy is losing speed, not as much speed as some thought, but not slipping into recession, that's how I would underline this first read of third quarter GDP. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Lauren. Thank you. We're going to dig deeper into these numbers, and just you just noted, the GDP overall was up 1.9 percent. You had consumer spending up 2.9 percent, but business investment down three percent for the third quarter.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is the president of Macromavens. She is Stephanie Pomboy. It's always a pleasure to have you, Stephanie. Thanks very much for joining us.

STEPHANIE POMBOY, PRESIDENT, MACROMAVENS: Pleasure to be here.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction.

POMBOY: Well, I guess, you know, it's very hard for me to dig into the numbers without some of the detail, but obviously, the headline print is a little bit better. It's a continuation, however, of the deceleration we have seen so far this year. The capex continues to be a key area of weakness, offset somewhat by the consumer. I think the real question, for me, is what were inventories in this number because that has the potential to really swing things one way or the other.

And we've been trying to unwind a fairly substantial inventory overhang so if there was less progress made in reducing inventories, which would have helped boost this number, that actually sort of perversely is a bad thing because it just leaves us with that much more stockpile going into the fourth quarter that to be liquidated presumably at lower prices. So, that's a question that remains unanswered for me anyway.

But, you know, the consumer spending number at 2.9 is, you know, better- than-expected. However, it's down sharply from the prior quarter and it's, again, a continuation of this broad deceleration we have seen.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

POMBOY: Which I think is kind of noteworthy in the face of the shift in Fed policy. I mean the whole reason why the Fed in theory abandoned its rate hikes and the quantitative tightening was to provide stimulus to the economy and instead, it appears that the most of the liquidity that they've added has flown to financial assets rather than into real growth.

BARTIROMO: What's your take, Kevin, on the -- on the other numbers like consumer spending up 2.9 percent, like capex down three percent? And let me also just tell you that the final GDP for the second quarter is unrevised at up two percent, so solid number for the second quarter.

O'LEARY: That's very good actually, but the real issue for investors is to decide what the Fed's going to do. The 25 basis point cut that we're about to get is baked in, but do these numbers, in a way, sway them to stop? Because I don't feel that these cuts are necessary anymore. The economy is doing a little better than even those that said it was going to slow at what rate would slow, it's not slowing as fast as people thought.

Trade uncertainty is holding back capex. That is irrefutable, that could be resolved when we get through the next year, that's the weakness that everybody's talking about, but the consumers' really on fire still. I can't see the Fed cutting again, that's what these numbers tell me.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll see. I mean the Federal Reserve's going to wrap up this two-day meeting today. We'll know at 2:00 today if the 90 percent expectation is right and that is another cut for the -- for the Fed funds rate at 25 basis points.

But, again, a lot of people expect that, that they're going to be done for a little while. Omeed, what about you?

MALIK: I don't know. I see this current Fed is making decisions based on global macroeconomic concerns not just what's going on in the U.S. So, if they did what I thought they should do would stay stagnant but I think they're actually going to cut because they look at the global economy and they're very concerned about trade as we've heard them say really many times.

So I do believe that they might do another cut. But I also think that that's probably priced in, because that's consensus.

POMBOY: Right.

MALIK: It's not feeling the kind of growth that we were going to see on some of these metrics that you described. The market definitely wants one, they always want one.

POMBOY: Right.

MALIK: But the question is, is whether that's good monetary policy and I don't think it is. And we spoke about that before. I think we're on a smart course with the economy, the deregulation, and we should stick to that. And the economy is fundamentally strong. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Stephanie, you mentioned business inventory. The numbers we have got for the third quarter's up $69 billion in inventory. Second quarter was $69.4 billion, and it says that the business inventory changed cuts, 0.5 percentage points from the GDP change for the third quarter. $69.0 billion for the third quarter. Second quarter was $69.4 billion.

POMBOY: That was less than --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

POMBOY: -- it was supposed to detract, so, you know, it's a margin, it helps explain why the number was better-than-expected. They obviously are making zero progress in unwinding this inventory overhanging, you know, at $69.4 billion. The $69 billion essentially no change whatsoever. So, again, this is going to be an issue going into the fourth quarter because we also got updated monthly, inventory data yesterday and that was stronger, you know.

The was more retail inventory which is exactly where you don't want it going into the holiday season, parallel inventory to sales rations are at all-time record highs. So that can be a drag, obviously, on fourth quarter GDP, and profit margins for companies in those areas, which sort of gets me into that whole I know we have earnings numbers coming out later and I think this is -- we have talked about this a lot, Maria. I look at the government profit data. We didn't get a look at third quarter profits for this report because they don't come out, that number, until the revision to the first estimate.

But in general, the government measure of profits has been running ay below. The numbers are S&P shows, and that's a function of this buyback bonanza because the government numbers aren't affected by buybacks and what it tells me is that if you take away buybacks, real earnings in the economy are not nearly as strong as investors perceive them to be and I think that that sets up a real potential comeuppance for the market when those -- that gap is eventually resolved as it has been every time in the past when the S&P numbers have run ahead of the government profit measure.

BARTIROMO: I mean I think the real negative here is the -- is the business spending down three percent.

MALIK: Yes.

POMBOY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Obviously the consumer stays pretty strong in but even tin these numbers --

MALIK: But you know why that's occurring.

O'LEARY: Right.

MALIK: This is trade war.

O'LEARY: Yes, that's uncertainty about this. Right.

MALIK: Exactly what that is.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes. Absolutely.

O'LEARY: And everybody knows that as totally transparent, the question is all these data sets we just looked at, does it change anybody's decision on whether to stay long U.S. equities? And my answer is no, you stay long U.S. equities, you're getting a 2.8 something percent yield on the SCC -- on the S&P, I mean, versus what else would you invest in?

BARTIROMO: Well, again, let's go to Stephanie because I know Stephanie's on the other side of that trade.

POMBOY: Yes, well --

BARTIROMO: You want to sell into equities right now?

POMBOY: And, my point on the whole idea that this is all trade related is that if you -- I mean, if you have a toothless trade deal with China, does that rally alleviate the issue for these companies. And also, at the end of the day, it really comes down to what can they sell? What is consumer? What is the end consumer demand? So if they saw that consumers were willing to buy right now, don't you think they'd be increasing production and selling more regardless of the trade issues.

MALIK: But ask yourself about (INAUDIBLE) if your mandate and there's billions that have this mandate is to make five percent for your pension. And you've got the plethora of options and places you can best in the world to make that five percent.

Does anything you see today change your mind about staying long U.S. equities making a 2.8 percent yield or maybe hoping for 200 basis points of capital gains in the next year. I say you stay long.

POMBOY: You're asking the wrong person because I think we're heading into 2008 all over again in terms of overvaluation of on market so I mean --

O'LEARY: That's very Chicken Little of you.

POMBOY: Uh-huh.

BARTIROMO: Why?

MALIK: Yes, but she makes such an important structural point though about how cheap that is for the companies to take on, which by the way on their balance sheets at its highest level ever and then repurchase stock.

POMBOY: Right.

MALIK: I just think --

O'LEARY: But what makes you think rates will go up in this -- in the next year.

MALIK: Well, actually that's the --- that's the counter exactly that we are in a position now where no one has the political will or fortitude to raise rates even if it's the right thing to do because we are in this artificial recovery.

O'LEARY: But again you're managing $20 billion. What do you do today with that?

MALIK: Right. Totally understand, your point is well taken. I think she's saying that at some point, the music stops like it always has. And that's the story for a decade.

O'LEARY: I've been to that story for two years.

MALIK: For a decade actually within this (INAUDIBLE)

O'LEARY: And if you had shorted this market two years ago, you've lost at lot.

MALIK: I totally agree.

POMBOY: You're seeing important cracks around the edges though at -- right where you'd expect to see it, on the front lines of risk.

MALIK: Right.

POMBOY: The uniform stocks have gotten pummeled recently. This whole WeWork thing I think is the tip of the iceberg for a lot of this companies that really, you know, basically, if you give someone enough money, they can lose their way to infinite valuations and that's been proven with (INAUDIBLE)

MALIK: That's for you private equity.

BARTIROMO: So what other -- what other cracks do you see that -- you just said we're headed to a 2008 all over again. That is a big statement.

POMBOY: In terms of -- yes, in terms of the stock market, potential for a correction in the stock market.

BARTIROMO: How significant correction would you expect?

POMBOY: At 50 percent.

BARTIROMO: Fifty percent correction of the stocks?

MALIK: Oh.

O'LEARY: Wow.

BARTIROMO: When -- with -- this year, next year, what?

POMBOY: Well, I mean I don't know over what timeframe in terms of how long it would take to get 50 percent I think once you start down turn going, it will accelerate very quickly. It's' going to snowball very quickly, thanks to, you know, vehicles like ETF, et cetera. but I would expect -- you know, I think this idea, if we get a China trade deal for example, I think that would be the moment the market will rally on that, and that's when you come in and you sell because the reality is I focus a lot on the consumer because it's really the lion share of the U.S. economy.

If you get that story right, you'll probably get the U.S. economy, right?

MALIK: Let me take the other side of that today.

POMBOY: And that consumer is not nearly as strong as people think.

MALIK: Forget the American consumer on a -- on a China trade deal, 46 percent sales of the S&P 500 now foreign, primarily in Asia. So if all of a sudden you clear the way for I.P. and you cleared the way to access to the market.

A lot of the growth in earnings are -- it's not going to be the U.S. consumer, it's going to be our ability to sell the Chinese consumer for the first. The market's willing to wait, and was willing to pay for that when it comes. In a way, this never occurred before. In the last 25 years, we've never got access to the Chinese middle class.

POMBOY: All right. I guess unlike you, I don't think there's any chance we are getting a deal on this.

O'LEARY: Oh, that's -- I don't agree with you.

BARTIROMO: You don't think we're going to deal on China?

POMBOY: I think we get a deal that's toothless, that doesn't address the intellectual property issues. And if we do get a deal that addresses intellectual profit, it's not going to have the enforcement or they are going to cheat or whatever. I don't think there's any chance that China is going to relent on that.

BARTIROMO: Well, I don't --

POMBOY: That's my -- just my opinion.

BARTIROMO: I don't disagree about China not relenting. This is a culture. They've been stealing intellectual property for decades. So, how do you change a culture and deal with just them buying more agricultural products is not the deal that Americas wants exactly true. Stephanie, it's great to get your insight.

POMBOY: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Thank you. Stephanie Pomboy joining us with her sobering view this morning.

POMBOY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Uber and Lyft meanwhile doubling down against a California law that would reclassify contract workers as full-time employees. Gerri Willis on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange looking at all that now. Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, Maria. That's right. So what we have is a big gig economy employers, Uber, Lyft, DoorDash, they're spending $90 million to get an initiative put on the California ballot to -- that would go against this law that reclassifies contract workers as full-time employees spending a lot of money. They'll have to get 600,000 signatures to get it on the ballot. That is a high hurdle.

But as you can see, this is important to those -- to those employers. Also this morning Fiat and Chrysler, Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot may team up, may merge. They're in talks to tie up as soon as tomorrow according to Reuters, that's what they're saying.

You see FiatChrysler up half a percent. PSA's board is expected to meet today. Just four months ago, FiatChrysler abandoned plans for a merger. And to the point you guys were making before, I was just riveted by your conversation. I can tell you traders down here like the economic numbers they saw today. We're not really seeing much of it in Dow Futures, but positive comments down here, Maria. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much. Gerri Willis. Coming up, the advance reading on the third quarter GDP coming in better-than-expected. The U.S. economy sees growth of 1.9 percent. Of course this is the first look at the third quarter. We're going to get two more revisions. Stuart Varney will weigh in on that.

Then the college athlete compensation story. Details behind the NCAA's new bid allowing college athletes to profit from their names. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Third quarter GDP coming in better-than- expected, up 1.9 percent. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & CO." Stuart Varney to weigh in here. It's a pretty good number, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Oh, it's -- it was very good as a matter of fact. 1.9 percent on an annualized basis, that's pretty good, more to the point, personal consumption up 2.2 percent. That's an indicator of how the consumer is doing. And the consumer is doing very well, as we head into the holiday season.

One more number, ADP, 125,000 new private sector jobs reported. Again, that is pretty strong. You add it all up, and it looks like this economy is beginning to turn the corner and start to expand a little bit more. I got great hopes for the fourth quarter, and the first quarter of next year, but you know me, I'm an optimist about the economy right, Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes, you absolutely are as am I, but there is a concerning issue in the GDP number.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And it is, of course, the capex spending.

VARNEY: Yes, it's down.

BARTIROMO: Down three percent.

VARNEY: It's down. Yes. It's not. I'm not trying to explain that, but you're quite right, it is a negative. But compared to all the other stuff that was in this report, on balance, I think it's a positive report.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it sure is. And there's two more revisions so I know you'll have more analysis coming up top of the hour, Stu.

VARNEY: We will. Shortly.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you then. "VARNEY & CO." begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart.

But firs, the college athlete compensation story. Details behind the NCAA's new bid allowing college athletes to benefit from their name. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back and a FOX Business alert. Former Secretary of State and ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson arrive at the tilson ExxonMobil climate change trail moments ago in New York City. He is taking the stand today. We will talk more about that as we understand the developments there.

We are also looking this morning at the NCAA taking another step toward college athletic compensation. The board announcing yesterday that it allow athletes to "benefit" from the use of their names, images, and likenesses, but did not specify if that means they can be paid.

Joining me right now is the Brewer Group CEO, former NFL defense back, Jack Brewer. And Jack, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks for being here.

JACK BREWER, CEO, BREWER GROUP: Yes. Great to be back with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What do you think about this?

BREWER: You know, this is a complex situation because the devil is really in the details here. You know, the NCAA, for so long, pushed back on this and I think, you know, California put them -- put their backs to the wall. Now you're seeing other states come forward as well, but, you know, this is really going to change the way that athletes are recruited.

There's a lot of things that you got to -- you got to think about when you talk about actually paying college athletes. A couple of those things are, you know, if a -- if a kid is going to school in a place like New York or California, you know, those schools are going to benefit tremendously by being able to give, you know, bigger name and likeness contracts to these athletes.

Another thing that California also mentioned in their bill is hiring of agents and I think giving an athlete the opportunity to hire an agent actually allows them to be represented, which is a big thing. But, you know, one thing that has really kind of teed me off a little bit, Maria, I must say is Senator Burr. I mean Senator Burr out of North Carolina, you know, he comes out and calls to actually tax the scholarships of college athletes. And I just think that's despicable.

BARTIROMO: Well --

BREWER: You know, it's really the -- it's the reason why a lot of Democrats find it hard to come across to the Republican Party. You have a man sitting here talking about taxing college athletes while normal academic scholarship students continue to go to school. You never heard them say one word about taxing them. An academic student can make as much money as they want.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BREWER: I mean it's ridiculous.

BARTIROMO: Well, look, Burr tweeted this out yesterday, and he said this, "If college athletes are going to making money off likenesses in school, their scholarship should be treated like income. It'll be -- I'll be introducing legislation that subjects scholarships given to athletes who choose to cash in to income taxes.

Then you also have Elizabeth Warren tweeting out, her take on it, and she said this. This is a good start. Now it's time to allow them to join a union and get paid, Jack.

BREWER: I mean I think the union idea is great. A lot of college athletes don't really have the financial background to go and representative themselves when they start talking about doing their own endorsement deals. You know, I'm big on financial literacy, Maria. You know that.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BREWER: I teach professional athletes now. But we need to put in place some of the measures that are going to prepare these athletes to actually go out and negotiate their own contracts.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BREWER: But Senator Burr, he crossed the line here. I mean he's a former college athlete himself. I think he played D.B. for Wake Forest.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BREWER: So to hear a guy like that come out and talk about actually penalizing the athletes when you let the normal students make as much money as they want, I mean it's despicable.

BARTIROMO: Well, let me get -- let me get Omeed in here and Kevin because they have comments about (INAUDIBLE)

O'LEARY: Jack, I want to ask you about just 20 years ago, there was no social media. Now if you're a star, college sports star, you can use your own platform to promote yourself as anybody would so what's wrong with, you know, reflecting that in the relationship with the NCAA?

BARTIROMO: All right. Real quick. And then Omeed, what do you want to say?

MALIK: I want to just piggyback off that. I think it's a great idea that they're allowing this, Jack, but I mean if they're going to have ordinary income independent of a scholarship where they have agents as you mentioned, then it makes sense. I think we're just trying to talk about something else, is taxing that income not the scholarship. Would you be OK with that? That distinction?

BREWER: Yes. Well, that's not what he said.

MALIK: No, no, no. I'm just asking you if that was the case.

BREWER: That's not what he said.

MALIK: I'll understand. I'm just asking.

BARTIROMO: Go ahead, Jack.

BREWR: Yes. That's not what he said. I would agree with that.

MALIK: Yes.

BREWER: Obviously a capitalist, too.

MALIK: Yes.

BREWER: And, Kevin, to your point, I mean let's get somebody's kids on "Shark Tank" and let them come up with their ideas to sell their own likeness. I think you'll have a lot there.

O'LEARY: I'm good with that, my friend. Great.

BREWER: But, you know --

O'LEARY: I'm a capitalist, too, I'm happy to invest in any of them.

BREWER: Yes. Thank God for that. But, you know, at the end of the day, for the senator to come out right away and talk about passing legislation that's going to tax their scholarship? Most of these kids will be making minimal amounts of money. I mean think about it, if you're, you know, a local kid, playing from -- for some school in the Midwest --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BREWER: -- or down south and you're not a big name, you're not a starter, you're not going to make a ton of money.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Jack, great to see you, sir. Thank you. We will see you soon.

BREWER: Yes. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Jack Brewer. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: It's been a great show. Omeed Malik, final word.

MALIK: The new law in California that makes Uber and Lyft employees not independent contractors doesn't pass the smell test. We can talk about it more later, but that's what I'll tell you.

BARTIROMO: We will do that. Thank you so much for joining us, everybody. Right to Stuart Varney we go in "VARNEY & CO." Stu.

VARNEY: And good morning, Kevin.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VS0-JFT1-DY19-C0J6-00000-00Social media giants have big responsibility2019-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisSocial media giants have big responsibility

The decision to force tech companies to increase their curation of social media is welcome, but there is a risk in rushing ahead.

The shocking footage live-streamed from the Christchurch mosque attack has convinced the federal government to take action against the social media companies that spread it around the world.

It is the right move but the legislation the government has just proposed puts Australia at the cutting edge of the global debate about where to draw the line of responsibility for social media. Before going too far, the government should ensure that any measures are proportionate and technically feasible.

Under the bill, the directors of social media companies that are found to have spread ??????abhorrent violent material'' and which fail to take it down expeditiously could face personal liability and up to three years in jail. It is possible even Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg could face jail. The companies would face fines of up to 10 per cent of global revenue. To give an idea of the potential sums at stake, Facebook has global revenue of $US55 billion and Google $US136 billion. This is strong medicine.

Attitudes to social media have shifted over the past decade. Once seen as agents of democracy and free speech, the giants of social media are now viewed by some as dangerous, multinational monopolies that flout consumers' right to privacy and show contempt for social norms. For example, Facebook was faulted for its role in diffusing fake posts by Russian trolls during the 2016 US elections and for allowing Cambridge Analytica to misappropriate personal Facebook data, which it used for political campaigns.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison has asked why social media giants, which are so clever at using artificial intelligence to tailor ads to customers, should find it so hard to block inappropriate content. It is a good question. The government says the proposed rules are not that new and are similar to legislation on child pornography and to the norms imposed on traditional media such as broadcast television. Yet social media companies are sure to raise objections. These could include the question of who decides what constitutes ??????violent abhorrent'' material.

Big tech has also stressed the practical problems and huge costs of taking down all the versions of an abhorrent post. By slightly altering specifications or switching to a different social media platform, a violent video can be made almost invisible to Facebook's internal net police and its artificial intelligence bots. Social media companies will argue that they are already devoting significant resources to dealing with this problem, and if the government takes too tough a line it will only drive violent material underground to the dark reaches of the internet.

On balance, the decision to force tech companies to increase their curation of social media is welcome. It is an area where self-regulation has failed. Yet there is a risk in rushing ahead. Australia has already picked a fight with big tech over control of content. The Coalition at the end of last year pushed through laws on data encryption that forced tech companies to give Australian security agents ??????back door'' access to their networks.

The laws are among the toughest in the world but the government rushed them through without a serious public inquiry, claiming they were needed urgently to prevent a terrorist attack over the Christmas period.

That haste was probably excessive. Microsoft global president Brad Smith was in Canberra this week complaining other countries might be scared to store data in Australia and Atlassian co-founder Scott Farquar has said the legislation was badly drafted and impractical.

That should be a warning to the government in the current case. This is a bold move and the government must take the time to ensure it gets the balance right.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60FK-55X1-F021-637W-00000-00Social media giants must act fast to remove 'appalling hatred', says Priti Patel;The Home Secretary intervened over 'abhorrent' posts by grime artist Wiley -who has now been handed a week-long ban by Twitter2020-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisPOLITICSVersion:1Social media giants must act fast to remove 'appalling hatred', says Priti PatelThe Home Secretary intervened over 'abhorrent' posts by grime artist Wiley -who has now been handed a week-long ban by TwitterBy, Pippa Crerar

The Home Secretary intervened over 'abhorrent' posts by grime artist Wiley -who has now been handed a week-long ban by Twitter

Social media giants have been told to act faster to remove "appalling hatred" from their platforms following anger over anti-Semitic posts made by grime artist Wiley.

Police are investigating a series of comments made on the musician's Instagram and Twitter accounts on Friday that led to him being banned from both for seven days.

In a tweet on Sunday, Home Secretary Priti Patel said: "The antisemitic posts from Wiley are abhorrent.

"They should not have been able to remain on Twitter and Instagram for so long, and I have asked them for a full explanation.

"Social media companies must act much faster to remove such appalling hatred from their platforms."

Government minister Robert Jenrick has echoed calls by the Home Secretary for social media sites to explain the length of time they took to remove posts made by grime artist Wiley.

The minister for housing, communities and local government tweeted: "I was appalled to see Wiley's antisemitic racist rant on social media yesterday, which should not have been able to remain online for so long.

"@pritipatel has asked Twitter and Instagram for an explanation, which as Communities Secretary I fully support.."

But the Government faced criticism for delays to bringing in the Online Harms Bill which could compel social media companies to take swift action.

Ministers first promised tough new legislation more than a year ago and has been accused of dragging its feet in taking on big tech firms.

Shadow Culture Secretary Jo Stevens said: "The failure to tackle these high-profile examples of hate speech shows why we so desperately need proper legislation to force the social media companies to keep people safe online.

"Social media companies have had repeated opportunities to show they can police their sites effectively. But when high profile individuals are allowed to keep their platforms after spreading vile anti-Semitic abuse -

and then doubling down when challenged -it's clear that self-regulation isn't working.

"The government promised this bill more than a year ago -it's high time they showed they take the safety of those who use the internet as seriously as the needs and influence of the big tech firms."

Following Wiley's posts, Twitter was accused of "ignoring anti-Semitism" as his tweets were still visible 12 hours after they were first posted.

A number of tweets have now been removed and he has been given a seven-day ban by the site.

A spokesperson for Facebook, which owns Instagram, said yesterday the rapper had been blocked from his account for seven days.

Twitter previously said Wiley's account had been temporarily locked "for violating our hateful conduct policy", while Facebook said there was "no place for hate speech on Instagram".

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T7S-4961-JCBX-G511-00000-00Social media giants must tackle child abuse2018-09-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 25Social media giants must tackle child abuse

LAST week, the Home Secretary laid down a much-needed challenge to big tech companies at the NSPCC's HQ in London.

Sajid Javid said he was demanding change to protect children from online groomers as well as urging the industry to tackle the vile trade in indecent images.

NSPCC research shows that the equivalent of one child in every primary school classroom surveyed has been sent a naked or seminaked image from an adult; and one in 50 had sent a nude or semi-nude image to an adult.

That is appalling, and it is something no child should have to experience.

Those images and messages are sent through social networks and texting apps, which recklessly expose children to content and behaviours completely inappropriate for their age, and now social net-works have become a gateway to child abuse.

Social media sites often know where we shop, what we buy and even where we go on holiday to target us with adverts - and if they can use that technology for profit, then why not to flag the risks to our children and proactively detect these groomers? The Government must now force social networks to tackle the problem blighting their sites, and that means changing the law.

The NSPCC's Wild West Web campaign is calling on Mr Javid and Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright to create an independent regulator, with the power to investigate and to fine social networks which fall short.

Social networks must also be forced to publish annual transparency reports about the scale of abuse on their platforms. In the coming months Government will publish its White Paper setting out proposals for what social network regulation could look like.

The NSPCC will be doing all we can to make sure these laws are fit for purpose, and we're asking everyone to sign our Wild West Web petition to tell Mr Wright and Mr Javid how important this issue is.

Ally Sultana, NSPCC

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XCW-4R91-F03R-N4YM-00000-00Social media giants must tackle #Disinformation before UK general election says Commission2019-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisSocial media giants must tackle #Disinformation before UK general election says CommissionEU Reporter Correspondent

Oct 30, 2019( EU Reporter: http://www.eureporter.co Delivered by Newstex) Social media giants Google, Facebook and Twitter must take 'serious further steps' to tackle disinformation[1] on their platforms by the end of the year, the European Commission has warned. The issue is now even more pressing with a general election announced in the UK for 12 December.

If the platforms fail to improve their record by year-end, the Commission has said it may introduce 'regulatory or co-regulatory measures', which could force tech companies to share their data more openly. This would allow journalists, developers and the research community to carry out analysis of disinformation operations. The UK Electoral Commission has also called for new electoral regulatory rules to ensure proper oversight and controls. The Open Knowledge Foundation has been campaigning to clamp down on the spread of disinformation on Facebook and other social media sites. Catherine Stihler, chief executive of the Open Knowledge Foundation, said: 'Facebook, Google and Twitter must act on the growing demands for greater transparency. The social media giants have been at the centre of a series of rows about disinformation, particularly in connection with the Brexit referendum, and that simply cannot be allowed to happen once again in the run-up to December's UK general election. 'Urgent action is required, and if the platforms don't act, then they need to be forced to. The institutions of the EU must use their influence to require online platforms to provide more detailed information allowing the identification of malign actors, put pressure on Facebook, Google and Twitter to increase transparency, and encourage closer working with fact checkers to prevent the spread of disinformation. 'The best way to tackle disinformation is to make information open, allowing journalists, developers and the research community to carry out analysis of disinformation operations.' Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W47-7N81-JCRP-C024-00000-00Social-media giants vow to combat online extremism but pledge lacks enforcement, U.S. participation2019-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisREPORT ON BUSINESSPg. B1Social-media giants vow to combat online extremism but pledge lacks enforcement, U.S. participationILL CURRY, TAMSIN McMAHONOTTAWA SAN JOSE, CALIF.

The world's largest social-media companies joined Canada and more than a dozen other countries in signing onto a global pledge to take stronger action to prevent the spread of violent extremism online.

But analysts largely see the agreement as a symbolic gesture that comes with no enforcement powers and lacks the backing of Silicon Valley's most powerful regulator, the U.S. government.

Canada is among 18 countries that said they would support the Christchurch Call to Action. The international agreement to tackle online extremism was drafted by New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern and French President Emmanuel Macron two months after a gunman used Facebook to livestream attacks on two mosques in Christchurch that killed 51 people.

In Paris for a summit of world leaders and technology executives, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said the international pledge is in line with Ottawa's national strategy on countering radicalization launched in December. "Today, we are stepping up to eliminate terrorist and violent extremist content online."

Amazon, Facebook, Google, Twitter and Microsoft released a nine-point plan to address extremist and violent content.

The promised measures include updating their terms of use and codes of conduct so that these policies "articulate a clear basis for removal of this content from our platforms."

Other pledges focus on: creating new ways for users to report terrorist and violent extremist content; imposing "appropriate checks" on livestreaming; producing transparency reports as to how these new measures are enforced; and working together on open-source or shared technology to detect and remove extremist content.

The voluntary measures come at a time when governments are debating whether to impose new regulations on the globe's web giants, including a push by some U.S. Democratic presidential candidates to break up big tech companies.

But the agreement lacks the support of the United States, where the majority of the world's largest technology companies are located. The Trump administration said on Wednesday that the United States would not join the accord, citing concerns about free speech, a move that highlights the growing divide with other Western countries over how to police social-media platforms.

"We maintain that the best tool to defeat terrorist speech is productive speech," the White House said in a statement.

The agreement is also voluntary and does not require countries that signed on to draft new enforcement policies. The accord also lacks specific details about how exactly governments expect tech firms to police their platforms and how those firms should be held accountable.

"This is a nice, non-binding agreement, where there are no mechanisms for enforcement that are being put in place," said Robyn Caplan, research affiliate with the Data & Society Institute in New York. "So for at least the short term, it will have pretty limited effectiveness."

In order to find a consensus, Ms. Ardern and Mr. Macron focused their efforts narrowly on violent extremist content rather than the broader system that enables dangerous content to be shared quickly across the internet.

"It makes it about a nationalsecurity issue and about violent extremism, said Taylor Owen, an associate professor of public policy at McGill University. "When really the problem ... is embedded in a much bigger set of problems about harmful speech, about data privacy and content moderation writ large across these platforms."

The agreement largely focuses on extremism in Western democracies and does not address the use of social media in countries such as Myanmar and India to incite political violence. "It's in a way like PR, because they're responding to France and New Zealand," said Joan Donovan, of the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University. "But we still have many, many instances of other kinds of hateful content, or whitesupremacist or fundamentalist content, that has also gone unaddressed."

However, analysts also say the joint consensus among so many countries could help embolden smaller democracies, such as Canada, that don't have the global clout to pursue aggressive regulations against large, U.S.-based tech companies.

In Ottawa, the House of Commons committee on access to information, privacy and ethics recently issued a summons for Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg and chief operation officer Sheryl Sandberg to appear as witnesses in relation to a Privacy Commissioner's report that criticized the company for not doing enough to protect the privacy of Canadian users.

Facebook spokeswoman Erin Taylor said the company will work with the committee to ensure that Facebook is "appropriately represented," but declined to say whether either would appear.

Minister of Democratic Institutions Karina Gould told reporters in Ottawa on Wednesday that the federal government is considering whether it needs to introduce further measures in addition to the voluntary actions that the companies announced.

"I think it's incredibly important that the Prime Minister is in Paris today with Prime Minister Ardern, with President Macron and a number of other world leaders to say that at the international level, we're not going to accept this kind of incitement to violence and violent content on these platforms," she said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6B-2HD1-DXVP-V4W4-00000-00Social media hearings: Five things to watch as Facebook and Twitter executives get grilled by Congress2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:52ZLexisNexisNEWSSocial media hearings: Five things to watch as Facebook and Twitter executives get grilled by CongressJohn Fritze and Maureen Groppe

WASHINGTON – Leaders of the nation's largest technology firms are expected to tell lawmakers in a series of high-profile hearings Wednesday that politics don't factor into their content decisions, pushing back on assertions made in recent days by President Donald Trump.

The one company that won't be making that argument also happens to be at the center of the president's attention: Google.

Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey and Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg will appear before the Senate Intelligence Committee at 9:30 a.m. ET for a hearing focused on the potential for foreign influence on their platforms, but the executives have already been girding for questions about perceived bias leveled by Trump and other Republicans.

"Twitter does not use political ideology to make any decisions, whether related to ranking content on our service or how we enforce our rules," Dorsey will tell the House Committee on Energy and Commerce in a separate hearing set for 1:30 p.m. Wednesday, according to prepared testimony.

The remarks were made public a week after Trump, without evidence, accused Google of offering users "rigged" results when his name is plugged into the company's search engine. A top White House aide later said that the administration is considering regulations for the company.

But the president's threats apparently have not fazed Google. When senators asked its top leaders to attend, the company instead offered a senior vice president. Lawmakers balked, and committee aides said on Tuesday they did not expect anyone from Google to testify.

Here are five things to watch for in the hearings:

How hard will lawmakers come down on Google for not sending their CEO?

Senators wanted Google chief executive Larry Page to testify, but the company offered instead Kent Walker, senior vice president of global affairs and chief legal officer. The result? Google will be represented with an empty chair at the witness table. Although senators rejected the substitute, Walker still submitted written testimony. In it, Walker says Google has fulfilled its commitments to be more transparent about election advertising and is improving interference protections around candidates and campaigns.

"Google knows that there is no reasonable regulatory intervention that is likely to affect Google. Google is deeply imbedded in our daily lives and habits," said Siva Vaidhyanathan, a professor of media studies at the University of Virginia who has written books on Facebook and Google. "I think the folks who run Google are too arrogant to stoop to answering to the American people."

Will Trump tweet?

While Facebook, Google and Twitter were crucial tools in Trump's ascension to the Oval Office, he's recently attacked social media companies. At a recent campaign rally in Indiana, Trump called out Google, Facebook and Twitter by name.

"We will not let large corporations silence conservative voices," he said.

His remarks came after he accused Google of ignoring his State of the Union address and said its search engine is "rigged." He also attacked Twitter and Facebook as unfair but did not offer specifics about his concerns.

Will lawmakers call for more transparency or regulation?

There are a growing number of proposals to regulate big tech making the rounds in Washington, among them a proposal to audit algorithms used by tech companies to determine what content users see, but there's not much the White House could do without the cooperation of Congress. That's despite the fact that Trump economic adviser Larry Kudlow recently said the administration is "taking a look" at federal regulations for Google.

"It's an election year, so inevitably you're going to hear more about regulation," said Paul A. Argenti, a professor of corporate communications at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth.

Ajit Pai, the Trump-backed chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said he hopes the hearings will shed light on whether social media companies should be more transparent about their business practices, including how content is managed and how users' privacy is protected.

"The issues of online transparency, privacy, and free expression raise the question of public oversight," Pai wrote in a blog posted Tuesday.

How will social media companies respond to charges of anti-conservative bias?

House Republicans are expected to ask Twitter about actions like its treatment of a campaign announcement posted by Rep. Marsha Blackburn, a Republican member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee who is running for the Senate from Tennessee. Blackburn's online video announcement was blocked in any Twitter advertisements last year because Twitter objected to Blackburn's reference to having stopped the "sale of baby body parts." After initially determining that "a small portion of the video used potentially inflammatory language," Twitter said it reconsidered the ad in the context of the entire message and allowed it to be promoted in her ads.

In his submitted written testimony, Dorsey says he wants to be clear that political ideology is not behind any decisions it makes. Both to "serve the public conversation" as well as "from a simple business perspective," Dorsey says, Twitter is "incentivized to keep all voices on the platform."

His testimony notes that #MAGA was the third most tweeted hashtag in 2017. And he shares the results of Twitter's analysis of a month's worth of tweets from members of Congress this summer.

Democratic lawmakers sent more tweets and had more followers than Republicans. Still, Dorsey said that after controlling for factors like the number of followers, Twitter found no statistically significant difference between the number of times a tweet by a Democrat was viewed versus a tweet by a Republican.

Will we learn anything new about foreign interference?

The purpose of the Senate hearing, in particular, is to assess how well social media companies are confronting foreign influence on their platforms. Top intelligence officials in the Trump administration have said Russia and other countries are working to sway voters ahead of this year's midterm elections. Facebook said in July that it had detected a covert campaign to influence the November elections through the use of posts on hot-button social issues, and it deleted hundreds of pages and accounts.

Facebook is expected to lay out the steps it has taken to address the problem, and is just as certain to face tough questions from lawmakers about whether they've gone far enough. Part of that effort includes a new "paid for" line that Facebook will require on political advertising.

"The meat will be a quantification of what Facebook is doing about fake sites," Vaidhyanathan said. "But I'm pretty sure that most of our attention will go right past that and go to the non-issue of political bias."
